column1: Databases are structured systems used to store, manage, and retrieve data efficiently. They are foundational to various applications by offering reliable data management and transaction capabilities. Here is an outline of key features found in most databases:
- Databases utilize different data models, organizing data into tables or collections, using structured (SQL) or flexible (NoSQL) schemas.

- Relational databases emphasize ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) for ensuring reliable transactions, while NoSQL databases may prioritize BASE (Basically Available, Soft state, Eventually consistent) for scalability and availability.
- Implement security features such as authentication, authorization, and encryption to secure data against unauthorized access and breaches.
- Enable multiple users to access and modify data simultaneously while maintaining data integrity and consistency.
- Enhance their performance through vertical (scaling up resources) or horizontal (adding more servers) scaling, with NoSQL databases being particularly adept at horizontal scaling.
- Provide mechanisms to regularly backup data and restore it, ensuring resilience against data loss and system failures.
